title: Data Standards in Audiology: A Mixed-Methods Exploration of Community Perspectives and Implementation Considerations
author: Charlotte Vercammen (Sonova AG), Antje Heinrich (University of Manchester), Christophe Lesimple (Sonova AG), Alessia Paglialonga (CNR-IEIIT), Jan-Willem A. Wasmann (Radboud university medical center), Mareike Buhl (Université Paris Cité), ...
relevance_why: This paper discusses data standardization in audiology which is relevant for developing robust datasets for tasks such as audio quality enhancement and restoration in Haohe Liu's research.
background: The development and implementation of standardized data formats in audiology, which aims to enhance data sharing and interoperability across clinical and research settings.
contribution: This paper introduces a mixed-methods approach to gather community perspectives on data standards in audiology, identifying key challenges and opportunities.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in audiology have lacked a consensus on data standardization, hindering interoperability and data sharing.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines quantitative survey data with qualitative expert insights to provide a comprehensive understanding of community needs and existing challenges.

key_innovation: Provides a community-centered approach to developing data standards, emphasizing the importance of stakeholder perspectives in shaping initiatives.
real_world_impact: This research has the potential to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of hearing healthcare services by promoting better data integration and usability.

new_terms.interoperability: **Interoperability** is the ability of different systems and organizations to work together (inter-operate), particularly in terms of technology and data standards.
new_terms.FAIR principles: **FAIR principles** stand for Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable data, aimed at making data more usable and auditable.
